No, I don't think Amir's growth would have been possible without confronting his past and taking responsibility for his actions. Amir's growth is the result of him coming to terms with his past and finding a way to move forward. Throughout the novel, Amir is haunted by his childhood mistakes and the way they have impacted the lives of those around him. It is only by facing up to these mistakes that he is able to start the healing process and become a better person.

Moreover, Amir's guilt and shame drive much of his emotional journey in the novel. He initially tries to erase his past, but as he grows, he realizes that he can't do that without facing the truth. By taking responsibility for his past and seeking redemption, he is able to transcend his own selfishness and become a compassionate character who is invested in his people's future.

In short, it is only by confronting his past and taking responsibility for his actions that Amir is able to achieve personal growth, transcend his own ego, and develop a more profound relationship with his country and its history.
